5.91.text: Well, thank you everyone for welcoming me.

8.96.text: I feel a bit jet-lagged, so I said no PowerPoint today.

13.29.text: I wanted to have a conversation and we've spent some time

16.44.text: talking about this class and about what you're learning and

20.21.text: about the center and so I'm really excited to be here.

22.82.text: I'm really excited to talk about how I started my company.

27.83.text: So that's like a very long time and I think it's

30.99.text: also because it's been a really long time.

32.75.text: So I want to talk about how I started.

35.33.text: I started my company back in 1996 and so it feels very ancient.

41.77.text: The tools I had available to me to do that and to start are very

46.72.text: different than what I think young entrepreneurs have today.

49.18.text: And so I want to talk a bit about how I started and focus on

53.35.text: the work we do at the agency and then what we do now.

56.19.text: And I hope to save kind of some significant time to have Q&A

60.47.text: and to engage with you and answer your questions.

63.27.text: So let me start off with how I started Buzz.

66.78.text: So I never ever thought I would be an entrepreneur.

69.85.text: In 1996 that was not a word that was really kind of known to me.

75.42.text: I always thought I would be a beauty editor.

77.44.text: So I was very focused on fashion and beauty and I wanted to be

81.86.text: an editor at primarily a teen girl magazine kind of like 17.

86.35.text: And so, at 16, I applied for a job with the newspaper for Girls out

91.75.text: of New York City called The New Girl Times and at the Times I primarily

96.45.text: wrote product reviews focused on - my first column ever was for a company

101.69.text: called High Intensity that made very cool jewelry.

104.90.text: And I found during that process of reviews that when I would

107.57.text: submit the column back to whoever gave me a product,

111.34.text: they would always say if I keep sending you

113.46.text: a product will you tell me what you think?

115.10.text: And at 16, I thought that was the coolest thing ever.

117.50.text: I thought there that there were tens of companies

118.75.text: who would send me products if I just told them what

120.39.text: I thought and so I thought that was the gig.

123.19.text: I didn't think it was a way to make money.

125.55.text: It was something I became really passionate about and even at 34,

129.43.text: I still - I'm so passionate about trends,

131.73.text: about new things, about whether it's reading about

134.13.text: a new destination in Conde Nast Traveller,

136.58.text: it's something that still fuels me today;

138.72.text: the idea that there are so many new products to try, so little time.

143.26.text: So back in '96, I remember a lot of PR-type people who were

150.19.text: my 'clients' and I started getting phone calls like

153.72.text: "I have a friend, she works on this brand.

156.10.text: You'd be really cool to talk to."

157.77.text: And I didn't really understand what the conversation would be.

160.73.text: I was literally a suburban teenage girl and I should - I guess -

165.30.text: go back and say I am the oldest of six children and so the

169.77.text: eight of us where I was kind of the odd kid doing this interesting

172.67.text: thing and since all of my siblings have really interesting

176.15.text: careers and do really interesting things,

177.65.text: but at the time it was something very different and very new and so

180.60.text: my parents were like why is UPS - why are UPS and Fedex here everyday?

184.62.text: So no one really got what was going on.

186.68.text: I didn't really get what was going on.

188.62.text: But it was happening really quickly and so by the time I was 17,

194.51.text: again, I use that word very loosely because I hadn't yet had that

198.61.text: moment where I realized I could make money doing what I was doing.

202.10.text: And so I started to recruit my friends and say

205.53.text: if I gave you guys some of these products,

207.57.text: can we all review them and I will tally our scores and

210.53.text: I will send this little report back to our client and so that

215.48.text: works for a while and then my friends would say well,

218.06.text: I have a cousin in Texas and she would love to be one of the your

221.48.text: trend spotters and again think about the time we're talking about.

225.06.text: I said, well, how would I communicate with her?

227.39.text: I had just gotten an AOL email address at 16.

231.27.text: So the idea of technology and connectivity wasn't

235.18.text: something that was yet really relevant,

239.23.text: And the way to communicate, the way our network communicates today,

243.31.text: didn't really make sense at that time.

245.98.text: So continued pretty small until I got to college

250.00.text: and as a freshman in college I had two real important

253.59.text: things that happened at the same time.

255.00.text: First, I took my intro to business course at Hood College;

258.96.text: I went to a womens' school, Hood College in Frederick, Maryland.

262.38.text: And I took an intro to business with the Head of the Department

264.73.text: and at the same time I was working on one of these reports for

268.80.text: a fashion company and my client at the time called and she said

272.43.text: I'm going to tell you something really important.

275.20.text: I reviewed it with my team and yours is 10 times

278.08.text: better than a report we paid $25,000 for.

282.85.text: it's called market research and that's all

284.48.text: I'm going to tell you, go figure it out.

286.05.text: And so during office hours I went into Dr. Jose's office,

289.61.text: I said here is what I've been doing for the last 2.5 years.

293.27.text: And she took some time and kind of just stared at me for a while and

296.71.text: then she said I want you to take an independent study with me next

299.50.text: semester and let's see if we can't make this a real business.

301.88.text: And so I was really fortunate at that

304.62.text: time to - like I always tell Dr. Jose,

307.73.text: I got beat up for 13 weeks in a row into

310.54.text: creating a business and marketing plan,

312.09.text: but I still use those plans today.

316.09.text: because when I was in college at that time,

317.51.text: so I think '97 to probably spring of '98,

321.03.text: it was right around that like .com

324.55.text: boom and so when Dr. Jose and I talked,

327.79.text: she said I don't want you to get caught up in what

330.30.text: at that point seemed to be a kind of trend.

332.34.text: She was like I want you to build a business that's a solid

335.23.text: business and if there is a digital component that's great,

337.43.text: but you've got to build a solid business and there

340.25.text: were - I mean I try - to help you understand what was

342.50.text: happening at this time in the Internet,

346.51.text: that were raising $50 million and then

348.77.text: went bust a couple months later.

350.82.text: So it was very different than I think kind of the builder moment,

354.67.text: that's happening now and in a little bit I will

356.53.text: get into some of the trends we're studying.

361.32.text: I need to build this solid business and I was really fortunate

364.57.text: that when I needed to understand statistics I could go and

367.51.text: talk to a professor and if I needed to understand how psychology

371.45.text: and sociology played into my business,

373.11.text: there were people that were available for me to talk to.

376.05.text: So of course I am a big advocate of building

378.98.text: businesses while you are in school.

381.14.text: I think that I always say my education definitely worked for me.

385.19.text: And it was really important for me to actively

388.97.text: be a student and also build this business,

391.59.text: and so I can - I worked with Dr. Jose and realized okay,

396.53.text: I have services, now I can make money and started working

400.45.text: really hard at recruiting clients and by the end of my

404.50.text: college career I was working with Verizon Wireless.

407.50.text: I remember spring of my senior year doing a research project for them

410.72.text: and flying to California and back to school for class and

413.90.text: I spent my junior year instead of staying abroad, I studied away.

418.67.text: which I really found to be kind of the Mecca for marketing

421.17.text: and so at 22 I'd had a lot of experience.

424.19.text: At this point, six years of running this business and I still

427.83.text: thought maybe this was just a really interesting hobby.

431.24.text: I didn't actually think this was going to be my

434.19.text: career for as long this has been my career.

436.32.text: And so I still remember the conversation

438.75.text: with my advisor when I said oh,

440.37.text: I had just watched legally blonde - I was just talking about this last

444.26.text: week in another conference and thought I should go to law school.

446.86.text: I don't know people who like fashion and

448.12.text: beauty go to law school, I don't know.

449.29.text: I remember her just saying yes,

451.77.text: you could go to law school because you're a very good student.

454.96.text: And not knowing that this is what I wanted to do,

457.92.text: and I had been getting some media and I thought that

460.62.text: the media was focused on my story of being this interesting

468.08.text: at 21, I didn't think that was the way to build a business;

472.45.text: so focused on one person, one story.

474.59.text: And I also didn't think it was the right story.

477.14.text: I didn't think it was the right message because at some point

479.42.text: you have to grow up and you have to be respected as a research

482.75.text: company or whatever is that we were becoming not there is this

486.64.text: school girl that does this cool stuff with the product;

488.61.text: I felt like there was a timeline on that.

491.08.text: And so I said to my advisor,

493.62.text: we really talked, spent quite a bit of time in different

496.11.text: sessions talking about should I go to law school,

497.79.text: should I do vastly different things,

501.48.text: should I go into the field and just apply for a job.

504.70.text: And I remember my girl friends senior year reading like this

508.79.text: book on quarter life crisis and it was really funny.

511.21.text: They were like oh, you of course don't need to read this book.

513.31.text: I'm like: I probably have the biggest crisis here of everybody.

517.44.text: But I decided, I said to my advisor at the time,

520.22.text: I said here is what I'm going to do.

521.91.text: I think that - when I graduated,

524.57.text: it was spring 2002, and illegal downloading had become

528.56.text: a major issue or it was becoming kind of thing.

530.97.text: You know, it was the Shawn Fanning movement and that sort of thing.

534.33.text: And during the spring of my senior year,

537.47.text: I spoke at a music industry conference.

539.99.text: It was a very interesting conference because there

542.25.text: were three other presenters from really,

544.29.text: really big research institutions and they were saying

547.35.text: things to the audience who you can imagine,

550.72.text: were people who were quite concerned about illegal downloading and

554.56.text: they were saying things like: it's not going to be an issue,

557.71.text: only 17% of people illegally download music.

561.10.text: And then I get up, this senior in college

564.89.text: who has a research panel at that time,

567.05.text: I should back up and say our network grew to 9,000 people

570.80.text: solely because CosmoGirl Magazine wrote two sentences

573.57.text: about what I was doing and I got 15,000 applications

576.52.text: from people all over the world who wanted to be

578.43.text: buzzSpotters and so we really created this great network.

582.50.text: And we had done research and found

584.51.text: of the 500 people that we surveyed,

586.77.text: that 99% of them had illegally downloaded

590.83.text: And so obviously we were presenting two very,

594.24.text: very different sets of data and so I kind of was disheartened,

599.79.text: I was cut out of an article and billboard and I thought okay,

602.87.text: well that is what it is.

604.36.text: And so back to that conversation with Dr. Weinberg,

608.06.text: I said, you know what I want to do,

609.27.text: I want to - I have always wanted to be a liaison

611.85.text: between consumers and people who target them.

614.18.text: And at the time it was teens and then as I grew

617.46.text: older it was the young adults and now I'm 34,

620.18.text: so we jut say consumers and people who market to them.

623.80.text: And I said well, I want to talk about things

626.48.text: that other people don't want to talk about.

628.89.text: And I don't have any skin in the game to necessarily

631.30.text: need to go one direction or prove one thing.

632.96.text: I'm really curious as to why consumers do what they do and what

636.69.text: their interests are and so presenting that research was to say,

640.32.text: you might be right, maybe only 17%

644.53.text: I just have a belief that the 99% that are in this demographic

648.38.text: I'm dealing with have a really huge impact.

651.20.text: And, obviously we know now that that did have

654.17.text: an incredible impact on that business.

655.97.text: I think still today it is impacting the music

658.89.text: business and how that business is shaped now.

661.18.text: And so, yes, that's always my example of the power of Millennials

664.82.text: and the power of consumers when they decide

667.62.text: that something is or is not working for them.

669.32.text: And so, I decided I was going to try that out for a year.

673.10.text: I opened an office in New York City and I work there.

676.85.text: I lived in South Jersey and I still live in South Jersey today,

679.36.text: and so did that for three or four years.

681.41.text: And I guess that most interesting thing that happened during

685.43.text: that time was I was featured in a cover story for O Magazine.

690.11.text: And so at 25, having that Oprah stamp

694.35.text: of approval on my career was huge.

696.45.text: I didn't think it would be.

697.79.text: Not that I didn't think the Oprah brand was huge;

700.87.text: I just didn't think anybody cared about a

702.33.text: kid who was doing research in New Jersey.

704.25.text: I just didn't think that was a story that would resonate with people and

707.68.text: obviously if you're lucky enough to be touched by the Oprah brand,

711.89.text: it does turn to gold if you're doing something good.

714.02.text: And so, it was great for us and I still remember clients

717.45.text: coming into the office like with my actual page from

720.33.text: the Magazine kind of like we saw this and so,

723.54.text: that was great for our agency and I think we kind of - again other

728.18.text: profiles and 30 under 30 and all kinds of awards which for me

733.47.text: and I think you'd understand if you're an entrepreneur,

735.38.text: you have to be fascinated by your work and passionate about

738.21.text: it and the other stuff is just stuff that happens.

741.29.text: It's not something you pause - and I think my mom,

744.03.text: I realized recently has a clip book of all of my different media,

748.53.text: but for me it was just this is another day and it's

751.35.text: another day that I get to do something that I love.

753.75.text: And so, we continued to grow the network,

756.61.text: continued with our research and then the economy took a turn,

760.73.text: which was interesting because what happened

765.01.text: So we got into influence of marketing, again, by accident.

769.06.text: I had a client call and say the girls I talk to about beauty

773.02.text: were having some issues launching a product at Sephora,

776.30.text: do you think we could engage them in influencer?

781.39.text: so I don't think - it was right around the time BuzzAgent was

785.40.text: coming along and I thought I don't know that we're that.

788.18.text: I've always really wanted that line of consumers being able to openly

793.83.text: and honestly express their opinions to brands and that was a really-and

796.86.text: still is-a very core value of our company and very important to me.

800.29.text: So that means if I have to say something that's not great,

803.58.text: that that has to be okay.

804.74.text: And that also is a big reason why I don't have a team of 50,

809.16.text: 60, 70 people because sometimes I do have to make decisions that

812.78.text: I think are a little more ethically driven for our business.

815.90.text: And so at that time I wasn't sure it would work and we

819.93.text: tried influencer and it worked really, really well.

822.61.text: And so we incorporated that into our services

825.28.text: and so when the economy took a turn,

827.70.text: it was a lot of traditional things that were getting

830.16.text: cut and people were reinvesting into the type of work

832.60.text: we do and so we have over the last 18 years,

837.27.text: worked with 135 companies and I guess some highlights for

841.53.text: me would be companies like American Eagle Outfitters,

847.39.text: and so we've gotten to touch some really big brands

850.58.text: and I've learned so much from our clients.

853.19.text: And I'd say personally for me,

856.61.text: one of the more fun accomplishments - a lot

858.73.text: of people talk about my business book,

860.12.text: but not so much about my children series.

862.05.text: So I write a series for 7 to 12 year old girls.

865.81.text: It's published by HarperCollins Children's Books,

869.70.text: And it's really focused on a girl I think is kind of like

872.05.text: a modern Ramona and I've written five books in the series.

877.52.text: So it's a really fun - I feel like it's my fun passion project.

882.16.text: I'm working on another series right now.

885.19.text: It's all about a girl who can't tell a lie and what happens

887.80.text: in middle school and so writing and creating McKenzie

892.18.text: and creating a character that is really beloved by girls

895.64.text: has been an interesting experience for me,

897.30.text: especially as a researcher, because through McKenzie,

900.47.text: through her life, I get to see girls react to her and really

904.08.text: get to understand kind of what's going on in the life of a 12-year-old

907.08.text: girl and that was something really interesting.

909.71.text: And then I guess as a final comment before

912.35.text: I open it up to your questions.

914.85.text: Two years ago, I was elected to

918.03.text: the United Nations Foundations Global Entrepreneurs Council.

920.93.text: And so we are charged with bringing innovative ideas to the UN.

925.69.text: And if I weren't working for myself,

928.03.text: I'd absolutely love to work for the UN and so

931.99.text: it's been a really incredible experience.

933.57.text: That's why I'm actually in San Francisco now.

936.84.text: it's our last, and so it's just been an unbelievable

940.61.text: experience for me for the last two years,

942.66.text: and earlier this year I got to spend some time in Uganda.

945.56.text: I got to visit a refugee settlement and meet entrepreneurs.

950.52.text: And when I think about what entrepreneurship means to me now at 34,

954.61.text: a bit more established and kind of what your opportunity is.

957.79.text: When I started out, there were not a lot of tools

960.59.text: and there weren't a lot of people that could help

964.43.text: other people rationalize what I was doing.

966.53.text: You guys live in a world where everybody

970.35.text: everybody knows what it means to be an entrepreneur

977.18.text: I was that girl doing that weird thing and people were

979.13.text: saying to my parents your daughter is so smart,

981.32.text: why isn't she a lawyer or a doctor?

983.05.text: They just didn't get it and so I'm now members of many different associations

989.78.text: that didn't exist when I started and so I think that the entrepreneurial

993.66.text: spirit and especially what I got to see in Uganda has really made me

997.99.text: an even bigger champion of entrepreneurship.

1001.56.text: Seeing innovation that can drive and create business opportunities

1006.30.text: in Uganda and meeting female entrepreneurs who are creating

1011.69.text: an amazing life for their children that are able to send

1014.19.text: their children to private schools just because they're entrepreneurs

1018.57.text: and they've simple businesses, selling soap, having farms,

1022.55.text: is something that was really interesting to see.

1025.27.text: And so, I guess at this point, I'd love to open-up for questions.

1028.73.text: We can talk about my work, we can talk about trends that I'm seeing;

1035.54.text: I know for a second you touched on like almost like an

1038.36.text: ethical quandary in your business from time to time.

1040.72.text: I was wondering if you could just elaborate on that.

1045.14.text: He was talking about really the ethics

1047.06.text: involved in what I do everyday.

1049.16.text: And I think that marketing is an interesting

1055.23.text: area when you talk about that, right.

1057.07.text: It's the images that we create, the messages that we send.

1060.97.text: I think that there was a time where I talked to my clients

1065.27.text: about kind of a one way funnel where we push things out

1068.61.text: to consumers and imagine when I was a teenager,

1073.22.text: I will use myself as an example,

1074.63.text: I feel like Gap dictated my whole life.

1076.75.text: It's like when their fall campaign came out,

1079.37.text: that's who I was, that is what I was going to be.

1082.01.text: And if I wanted a really specific shoe, there was no online shopping.

1087.40.text: I went to a mall that dictated what

1089.43.text: I had access to and that was that.

1092.17.text: If I was this suburban Jersey girl,

1093.79.text: this is what I could have access to.

1096.17.text: And I'm sure we remember those times where our friends

1098.27.text: would travel to the West coast and would get something

1100.33.text: there that we couldn't get at home.

1101.89.text: And so I think it created this funnel where marketers

1105.58.text: could project onto consumers what was cool.

1111.34.text: I think there was a particular one I saw call

1114.32.text: the Merchants of Cool where Sprite actually said,

1116.71.text: we project onto you the image of who we want you to be.

1120.04.text: And that for me was definitely a bit of an ethical dilemma

1123.88.text: and I think I was coming about in a time where technology has

1128.63.text: created this interesting democracy where consumers can,

1133.56.text: I feel, have the power and can dictate things to brands.

1137.57.text: Gap changed its logo, consumers didn't like it,

1140.15.text: they changed it back to the old one.

1141.63.text: That would never happen in my opinion 20 years ago.

1144.50.text: I think your ability to shop online and to make those

1148.66.text: types of decisions totally changes the playing field.

1153.46.text: It's if I don't like this, I won't do it.

1155.43.text: If I don't want to buy a car, I can use Uber now.

1159.04.text: If I want to be a conscious consumer, there are ways I can do that.

1161.85.text: And so I think that for me,

1165.56.text: I have always erred on the side of just working with brands that

1168.16.text: I really like and brands whose products I'm passionate about.

1173.03.text: And it's hard, because there are some - for me,

1177.49.text: can I say, I always feel passionate about Dell,

1183.88.text: I may not have - the products I got to work on were

1186.06.text: amazing products for people who need PCs.

1188.79.text: But what I was really passionate about was Michael Dell's

1192.71.text: entrepreneurial spirit and that he is really a true entrepreneur

1196.25.text: who is fascinated by new things and creating new things and

1200.10.text: so that for me was someone I could get behind.

1202.89.text: And I think that in general,

1205.59.text: I would tell you 90% of the people I've worked with have really

1208.85.text: wanted to connect with this consumer and the people who wanted

1212.89.text: to dictate to them weren't people that would work with my system

1215.40.text: anyway because the consumer and that research and data,

1219.11.text: we have a process we call connect-brand-impact-understand and the first

1223.05.text: step in that process is bringing in the voice of the consumer.

1226.29.text: So you can imagine if you're a marketer that you already have

1228.48.text: your plans and you just want me to verify what you're saying,

1231.36.text: we probably wouldn't the best match.

1233.05.text: So I think that earlier in my career it was something that probably

1237.76.text: came up a lot more where now I feel like it's the reverse for brands

1241.03.text: who are understanding that you dictate what's going to happen and

1243.40.text: they're just trying to figure out where they fit.

1248.11.text: What methods do you use or like where do you look

1250.82.text: to spot trends and what trends are going on today?

1254.56.text: Where do I look to - where do I spot trends?

1256.38.text: I was at Starbucks today and I was sitting next to very interesting

1260.36.text: Millennial having a conversation about her job at Salesforce and

1264.16.text: her co-workers and I wish I could have taped that conversation.

1267.05.text: I was fascinated by how quick it was happening

1270.34.text: and what she was talking about.

1272.24.text: And so I travel quite a bit, I travel outside the U.S

1275.88.text: quite a bit, but I don't believe that great

1278.95.text: trends are started in New York and LA.

1282.29.text: I think that, especially today, trends come from all over the place.

1289.52.text: And I'm really fascinated by people,

1292.37.text: and I think that to think that you can go to one place and

1296.28.text: one source and get everything you need is very antiquated.

1300.43.text: There was a time when people would produce a trend report and send

1304.62.text: it out and say to everybody these are the colors of the season.

1307.69.text: And I think going back to the technology piece,

1311.41.text: consumers are - it's so fascinating to me.

1315.18.text: Think about when fashion blogging became a thing, right.

1319.58.text: So think about a magazine like Lucky that when you open Lucky today

1322.71.text: I feel like fashion bloggers drive that book where years ago it was

1327.22.text: editors dictating to us what was cool and what was edgy and now we

1330.99.text: look at really cool people and those are who - I think Olivia Palermo

1335.45.text: probably tells more people what's cool than a fashion editor.

1338.64.text: And so it's interesting to see that power play where

1341.13.text: now it's like we all have to work together.

1343.53.text: And so for me commuting is a great time.

1348.97.text: I can always tell when a trend is massed

1353.69.text: based on my time in the airport.

1354.96.text: I'll give you an example of two: Uggs and Toms.

1358.17.text: When you get on a plane and everybody walking past you no

1361.01.text: matter what age is engaged with a certain type of brand,

1364.16.text: that's when you can start to see mass influence and there

1366.97.text: are times where I remember seeing two people at an airport

1370.29.text: with Toms and then I remember every other person having

1373.33.text: a pair of Toms and so I'm always looking at that moment,

1376.80.text: that breaker moment when something is really becoming mass.

1380.21.text: We had a trend a couple of years ago, we called massclusivity,

1382.58.text: which is the idea that everybody wants mass

1385.83.text: products that are customized for them,

1390.31.text: So I don't think that trends come from

1395.79.text: just one place or just one person,

1397.63.text: because at the end of the day my clients want volume and so we're

1403.44.text: right now creating something called the Millennial brand index

1406.27.text: where we're ranking brands in many different categories.

1408.70.text: And I'm talking to someone who is going to be part of a judging

1412.85.text: panel for this project and she said to me you're talking about

1416.06.text: all these companies that are really interesting.

1417.58.text: Of course the ones that I like,

1418.97.text: like Warby Parker - I love Warby Parker.

1420.80.text: She said what I want to know is if the

1423.45.text: girl in Kansas loves Warby Parker.

1425.46.text: And I think that is a great question because we sometimes

1428.55.text: can become a little obsessed with what's happening on the Coast

1431.58.text: and we don't realize it's a huge company - a company - huge

1434.58.text: country with so many different opinions and so I try to not

1439.25.text: let one idea dictate when I think something is cool.

1443.24.text: And I also don't think that I had the answers.

1446.87.text: I think you find a lot of people,

1448.47.text: I don't know if you guys experience this,

1450.32.text: I see it a lot in business where it's

1451.57.text: like because I have a child who is 12,

1453.39.text: I understand all 12 year-olds or I know Millennials,

1458.73.text: And what I - I always take the approach is that I don't know anything

1462.37.text: and that I think everyday something is changing and everyday

1466.04.text: I'm getting new access to new research and information,

1469.31.text: and so I always try to approach it from I'm just here to learn and to

1472.57.text: observe and to interpret and I don't really have an end goal from it.

1476.39.text: I just want to know what's interesting.

1478.03.text: And so, I think you have to kind of do the work I do,

1482.10.text: just be very open to learning something new and not - I

1484.62.text: think the most important thing is to not go into it,

1490.55.text: And sometimes I think that's hard with my clients because they

1494.15.text: sometimes arrive at the end and then want me to justify it.

1498.11.text: And so that's sometimes creates a dilemma I think.

1505.78.text: I'm just wondering, perhaps on a more personal thing,

1508.42.text: in the past few flights you've gone on,

1514.16.text: I think - oh and I have to answer your question, sorry, about trends.

1517.27.text: I will tell you a bit about the trends

1522.44.text: I think what I'm noticing lately is what's missing.

1528.27.text: I don't think we've figured out a charging solution

1532.52.text: that makes sense for as many devices as we all have.

1535.75.text: I see a lot of people crowding around very few outlets,

1542.15.text: I see in general airports becoming

1548.64.text: a more interesting hub of shopping and,

1551.07.text: specifically, I can speak to Philadelphia.

1553.57.text: It's not a joke that like the best shopping is in the airport.

1557.00.text: And so the airport as a destination but just from people in

1561.37.text: general it's that they want to be connected and that we've

1564.27.text: got to figure out how to make that connectivity easier.

1567.31.text: When you go to many other places outside of the U.S.,

1571.14.text: it's really easy to get online and to

1573.22.text: have great Wi-Fi and to be online.

1575.78.text: And so figuring out that issue and it's funny,

1582.41.text: I see a problem of food quality in airports and what

1585.97.text: consumers are looking for and what they've access to.

1588.28.text: So I think I see kind of more opportunity.

1591.61.text: And then in general with consumers, it's very interesting.

1598.99.text: There was a time where teenagers were called screenagers,

1601.75.text: because they were looking at so many screens.

1604.90.text: And what fascinates me is looking at boomers.

1607.23.text: I think everyone is so Millennial focused that they

1610.38.text: don't realize that there are other generations that

1612.06.text: there were really interesting things were happening.

1614.47.text: And so I think watching kind of the non-Millennial engage in technology

1619.64.text: with technology with so many different forms of technology,

1622.86.text: and figuring that out is something that's interesting.

1625.10.text: It's to really see how integral it is and that

1628.73.text: I think we're still a little bit behind.

1630.31.text: It might probably not be the case here.

1632.47.text: But there are places where what consumers need in that space,

1636.64.text: and how connected they want to be and that connectivity

1639.73.text: is not available at that moment.

1642.05.text: And in general to your question about other trends,

1644.15.text: so we've got working on our top 10 trends of 2015 right now

1650.77.text: and we're focused on some things like the Makers movement.

1654.16.text: And talking to some of our buzzSpotters,

1657.52.text: what's interesting is there are those that consider themselves

1660.95.text: real makers who really make stuff and they are really put

1664.06.text: off by the idea that everybody thinks they're a maker,

1667.44.text: but I just think it's something that's becoming a bigger

1670.10.text: consumer play and we are seeing it in different areas.

1672.35.text: I was on my flight over reading an article in Marie Claire,

1676.21.text: when they were talking about how to make the perfect

1678.46.text: palette and you can buy this palette called a Z palette

1681.29.text: that - it's a plain palette and you can literally,

1683.57.text: if you want to put your make-up in the oven and you can unglue

1686.77.text: it and create your own palette and so I thought about how

1691.55.text: interesting it is that we deconstruct make-up that we pay

1693.80.text: a lot of money for to create our own custom solution.

1697.25.text: And so we've talked a lot about customization

1701.30.text: before and the need for customization,

1704.13.text: but to actually give consumers the ability to make things

1707.82.text: and participate in this different way is something new.

1711.74.text: We're talking about this idea of being selfie-conscious

1714.88.text: and it's not at all that Millennials are self-conscious.

1718.67.text: It's that I feel like, and through our research we have seen,

1721.85.text: that there is such an emphasis these days on perfection.

1725.55.text: There was a time where it was like you could just walk out,

1729.70.text: I mean I went to college at a time where girls were

1732.22.text: going in like pajamas and Uggs or whatever boots

1734.69.text: they were wearing at the time, or Sneakers.

1736.04.text: And so, to think of a time now where everyone has to - think of

1739.85.text: your Instagram feed and how good everybody looks all day long.

1744.05.text: It's that pressure of you have to look good all day long,

1746.77.text: because there is no filter for that.

1748.77.text: And why didn't you get into this top college

1750.63.text: and why aren't you going to this top...?

1752.47.text: And so it's the pressure to be in all the right places

1755.06.text: doing all the right things and looking good and not

1757.10.text: looking stressed that I think we're looking at.

1759.32.text: And that data is really important to our clients,

1762.36.text: because as they start to create brand messages it's important to understand

1766.26.text: just what's going on in life for the average Millennial.

1769.72.text: And I think we were exploring another trend called Instafeed,

1773.13.text: but I think the team is like moving that into selfieconscious

1775.65.text: where I was looking at the continuous feed that we live in where

1778.64.text: every moment in our life is something we're documenting and not

1781.23.text: just living and how does that affect things in general.

1788.12.text: Fitness and wellness, and it's interesting.

1790.76.text: Again, I hadn't read Marie Claire in months,

1793.08.text: so I was catching up and listening

1794.25.text: to the - reading this editors letter,

1795.94.text: and she was talking about how they're totally changing

1797.68.text: the health section of the magazine and it's no longer

1800.65.text: about like how to do the perfect crunch,

1802.93.text: it's now about like a much more lifestyle approach to fitness.

1806.66.text: And again Instagram has become a big

1809.55.text: inspiration for this kind of thing,

1811.07.text: but thinking about the images of people who are so healthy.

1813.62.text: I mean, how many people pop up in your feed that are like I am

1816.94.text: working out and people like Jen Salzer or whatever her name is,

1821.10.text: who are in Vanity Fair for how amazing their butt looks.

1824.08.text: And so, again, it's the power of image and how

1827.70.text: that's coming across in that medium to say,

1829.47.text: okay, now I have to be fit.

1830.79.text: And think of it like soul cycle, whether you go or not,

1834.26.text: you know what this thing is, right.

1837.54.text: I love when workouts are called culls,

1839.05.text: but it means that they're building some kind of brand

1842.27.text: culture that people associate with in some way,

1845.06.text: and so we are looking at that.

1849.53.text: it's something that's come up over - that's one of

1853.32.text: those moments where I said I never tried to say

1857.37.text: what I think a Millennial will or won't do.

1859.68.text: I remember when we did our original research

1862.76.text: on net neutrality and I said,

1864.04.text: I don't even know if this is an issue they even know about.

1867.92.text: And I was so wrong, just in - and not only the

1871.40.text: knowledge but also why it was important.

1875.00.text: And I think that there is an interesting trend happening now

1879.19.text: where traditionally parents told children what to do, right.

1883.00.text: And they were the authority and we've explored this in different trends

1886.31.text: like hand-me-ups where Millennials were actually handing up older

1889.67.text: phones to parents because of shared cell phone plans and the Millennials

1893.54.text: were getting the better technology and there is also this divide where

1897.73.text: they're also explaining technology and that's something that's become

1903.13.text: a really interesting thing to explore, right.

1905.10.text: When you think of very traditional companies,

1909.59.text: grocery stores, how they talk to consumers about what's important

1912.67.text: and their issue - their image of family and what they project,

1915.81.text: a trend of who - it becomes a lot of like who is the making the main

1921.36.text: decisions in the household and so exploring that kind of trend.

1927.74.text: I'm trying to think if there is anything

1931.27.text: I mean, that's a preview so far.

1933.53.text: I think I like selfieconscious, I like looking at what that means,

1940.16.text: and looking at how also, to your question of ethics,

1943.84.text: are we as marketers putting that pressure there to look perfect

1948.16.text: and saying that perfection has never been more affordable.

1951.68.text: You can dye your hair in 10 minutes, why would your roots be showing?

1955.89.text: As we create really easy fixes to things I think

1959.27.text: we also don't allow room for imperfection.

1962.48.text: And so, that is creating - it becomes a predictor of will you,

1968.97.text: as a generation, pushback on that.

1972.45.text: I think we also look at your position on government,

1978.15.text: and this has been a really interesting thing.

1980.26.text: We pull this a lot and we found that in general Millennials

1985.08.text: might be a little more centrist than people think.

1987.06.text: When we did research five or six years ago,

1990.00.text: the percentage of Millennials that said that they were

1992.02.text: Democrat was much larger than what we are seeing today.

1997.83.text: But then also we are looking at the implications

2001.51.text: of - even if they're - number one thing,

2007.64.text: We did two types of identification.

2009.65.text: Are you Democrat, are you Republican or are you independent

2011.88.text: or do you think that you are more centrist?

2013.79.text: Like we used different words and got different responses.

2016.52.text: And then becomes the idea, totally separate idea,

2019.67.text: that they don't think government is actually working for them

2023.14.text: and in that case they feel like other Millennials or other

2026.45.text: people are better solving problems outside of government.

2029.68.text: And MTV has done a lot of research and a lot of work around this,

2032.79.text: and that really creates an interesting conversation around

2037.51.text: problem-solving and if Millennials start to approach problem-solving

2045.21.text: And so I think this is the year for us asking really interesting

2050.11.text: questions and just looking at metrics and data.

2052.44.text: I think it's one of those kind of transitional years to say,

2055.27.text: okay, like we know the traditional things are happening,

2057.93.text: like digital is more important than ever before that

2060.32.text: you're digital natives and that for brands they have

2063.07.text: to speak in this way but it has to be authentic.

2064.61.text: Like I think so many of those things now are known.

2067.43.text: I think what's happened is that it's become a year

2071.22.text: of like I don't know if you all ever feel this way,

2074.04.text: but I feel like people talk about Millennials

2075.92.text: like a species they've never seen before.

2078.14.text: Instead of just understanding like you have to engage

2080.67.text: like you would with any other demographic and there are

2082.97.text: lot of people out there that talk about what what what

2085.30.text: what what all day long and no one talks about how.

2088.16.text: And so I think for us as an agency next year is

2091.72.text: really about having conversation about how.

2094.04.text: How do you engage, how do you know what's important and how do you

2097.39.text: take into consideration all the trends we have talked about from massclusivity

2102.76.text: to a couple of years ago we talked about warholism,

2105.02.text: which is the idea that all Millennials believe they can be famous.

2107.95.text: It's not as interesting as it used to be.

2110.62.text: I remember growing up at a time where only seven real people

2114.17.text: ever made it to TV and they were on MTV's Real World.

2118.06.text: Now think about your younger siblings,

2120.58.text: you can record your own show on your iPhone,

2122.94.text: cut it, put it on YouTube and you're instantly

2130.06.text: And so, can people sell you fame the way

2133.49.text: they used to be able to sell to my..?

2135.08.text: And I guess I'm technically still considered a Millennial,

2138.68.text: but I'm the oldest of the Millennials.

2141.18.text: So I might even be like the youngest GenXer.

2143.46.text: And so, the power of celebrity to someone my age

2148.48.text: is very different and I even take it younger.

2154.07.text: it's a karaoke machine that you hook into your TV and a little girl,

2158.60.text: little boy sings her favorite songs and sees their face on TV.

2162.72.text: How do you then explain to them there

2164.22.text: are people who are super famous?

2165.78.text: You mean on TV like I was just on TV two seconds ago?

2168.87.text: So that idea of what fame truely means,

2172.47.text: I think, is something that's really changing.

2175.25.text: Also I was probably into my 20s before there was Perez Hilton,

2179.95.text: but the minute you start drawing on celebrities' faces,

2183.03.text: kind of it's an interesting value proposition.

2186.97.text: That's why we start to talk about this bigger concept

2189.54.text: of are there really true celebrities left?

2193.41.text: Because I think that there are entertainers,

2197.17.text: there are people that we allow to entertain us,

2199.38.text: but are there people that we kind of uphold as this unbreakable

2204.08.text: celebrity image that there was when I was growing up.

2206.63.text: I don't necessarily know that that exists.

2208.20.text: So I think that there are a lot of questions to answer right now.

2211.11.text: So, Tina, especially in a business where it's all about understanding

2216.73.text: people and given your fascination with people and having seen

2220.62.text: so many different types over your career,

2222.94.text: what would you say has been the most interesting or meaningful

2225.74.text: or valuable thing you've learned about people,

2228.35.text: and how has this impacted the way that you interact with people

2230.97.text: on a daily basis or chose to approach your business?

2236.98.text: So I would say ... Can you repeat the question?

2238.94.text: Sure, I will repeat the question.

2240.27.text: So I was just saying that I've seen so many

2242.87.text: people and interacted with so many people,

2244.51.text: I guess who, what segment or what groups have

2247.13.text: the biggest impact on me and how I see things?

2250.04.text: Is that pretty much the essence?

2253.10.text: Yes, and I guess just meeting people in general,

2255.44.text: what's been most valuable that you realize about what motivates them?

2260.10.text: So I think there are probably two experiences.

2262.96.text: First, I would say post recession talking with Tweens,

2269.81.text: because they've more technology than we've ever had.

2273.65.text: It is something that's like digitally native for them.

2276.66.text: So I explain it like for people my age

2280.00.text: we didn't have to discover TV, right.

2281.87.text: It's always there, it was always interesting,

2284.10.text: it wasn't a big new thing that happened in our lives, we get it.

2288.82.text: Same way a seven, eight year old sees technology

2291.46.text: and when I was writing my book,

2293.13.text: I had this theory that technology was ruining Millennials.

2296.57.text: And what I actually realize is that it's the other

2299.22.text: generations that have the biggest issue,

2301.51.text: because Millennials have always had it in

2303.09.text: a very appropriate place in their lives,

2306.04.text: in your lives where it is what it is.

2308.41.text: I can - and when you want to spend time with friends,

2311.48.text: I find that the engagement can be much

2313.67.text: more - I hate to use the word real,

2316.43.text: but you understand the place of technology.

2319.01.text: And so that was an interesting finding.

2320.30.text: And so when I think about Tweens,

2322.18.text: their access to information and just how smart they are,

2328.33.text: I mean, we were doing some research and my favorite quote ever: we

2331.80.text: asked Tween girls how has the recession impacted you and a girl said

2336.83.text: I have not been impacted at all: my grandma just gave me $20.

2340.17.text: And I thought I just love the optimism in that.

2342.89.text: My life is great, I have $20, life is awesome.

2345.97.text: And I love that for them anything is possible.

2349.99.text: They're not quite yet at the age where they

2352.38.text: have any reason to kind of be defeated.

2355.46.text: I'm going to keep moving and I've got the tools to do it

2358.42.text: and so when you see girls who can mix their own music or

2362.70.text: what technology is doing and allowing children to do,

2365.65.text: and how imaginative they can be,

2368.64.text: And I'd say another group - when I was in Uganda and met

2373.33.text: entrepreneurs there I realized that we truly do not understand

2377.17.text: what it means to run businesses with challenges.

2379.39.text: I walk into a room, I know that if I

2382.75.text: flip the switch the lights will work,

2384.48.text: I know where the nearest bathroom is,

2385.91.text: I know how to get out of the room in an emergency,

2388.50.text: I know that if I send an email my internet is going to work,

2391.13.text: and to go to a place where none of those things are certain and to see

2395.19.text: people still work so hard and come up with unbelievable solutions.

2400.07.text: I was on a remote island called Bussi Island and met an entrepreneur

2404.89.text: who had developed a solar backpack that basically lit this clinic where

2410.05.text: women would have to go if they could get there to give birth.

2413.52.text: And when - if they happened to give birth at night, there was no light.

2417.69.text: So babies were born and the first thing

2420.79.text: this baby is doing is inhaling smoke.

2422.84.text: And so, we don't think about those things,

2425.47.text: about the impact of those things and to see an entrepreneur -

2428.33.text: they came up with a solar backpack,

2429.81.text: now there is lighting, simple solutions.

2432.11.text: And so I think so many of us spend so much time thinking

2436.57.text: about very complex things and to see entrepreneurs

2439.89.text: focus on things that might seem so simple,

2442.41.text: but were so life changing for so many people.

2445.29.text: We also met a group of Stanford students,

2448.16.text: recent graduates who were living in Uganda,

2450.47.text: and had come to open a company focused on clean cook stoves.

2455.87.text: And it was amazing, because no one understands

2458.88.text: the importance of a clean cook stove.

2460.64.text: That if you cook up over an open fire,

2462.72.text: it is the equivalent of smoking five packs of cigarettes a day.

2465.65.text: And think about the fact that most of these women are doing this with

2468.14.text: a child on their back and so the child is also inhaling smoke.

2471.43.text: They came up with a solution that's less than $10 that heats

2474.58.text: food in this kind of clay pot for five hours and so to see how

2481.69.text: the developed world was working with the developing world,

2485.44.text: And I have spent so much time,

2487.80.text: I think, trying to think of these really grand ideas and to see

2491.58.text: that something so simple meant so much to so many people,

2497.86.text: And the last one was - actually this was a day,

2502.03.text: Global Accelerator, it was an entrepreneurship day

2503.89.text: at the UN and entrepreneurs were pitching us ideas

2507.29.text: and one guy had created a bicycle ambulance,

2512.19.text: which really made sense for parts of Africa,

2516.45.text: And again, we think of such big technology and this

2519.61.text: was really the safest best solution at $1,500

2523.84.text: and the statistics and research he had

2526.68.text: done on how many lives he has saved,

2529.30.text: And so I think that I walked away from that trip

2532.77.text: realizing that it's the small innovations that

2535.51.text: sometimes can really have the biggest impact.

2538.18.text: And if you take away the comfort that we're used to

2540.77.text: and we just had to - there are so many entrepreneurs.

2543.69.text: People who created clean filtration systems that changed

2546.87.text: the lives of children at boarding schools.

2548.73.text: So the idea that I think for me at this stage is thinking

2551.90.text: how simple can we be to come up with solutions;

2556.35.text: Yes, sorry I can't see you.

2559.23.text: I will ask a couple, if there is room, if we have time.

2562.67.text: So should I stand up or is it ...? Okay,

2565.29.text: so I've got a couple of questions I want to ask

2567.52.text: to make sure that these guys get answers too.

2570.55.text: You're in the business of separating -

2574.56.text: And I think one of the biggest areas of noise

2577.42.text: or questions is what should I do with my life?

2580.37.text: And lots of people have passions.

2583.58.text: Few people are able to pursue their passions and

2585.56.text: actually convert those into real businesses that

2587.46.text: they can make a livelihood after and thrive in.

2590.86.text: How do you know - and you have done this multiple times,

2595.77.text: when is there enough of a signal to indicate that a personal

2598.81.text: passion has - you should have enough conviction behind

2602.17.text: that personal passion to pursue that as a business when

2605.79.text: your parents are saying go to law school,

2607.36.text: go to medical school or all of your friends

2609.58.text: are going and working for the hot company?

2613.54.text: So I'm a big fan of not drinking your own Kool Aid.

2618.98.text: I think first, I always start with what are you passionate about,

2621.97.text: because the thing that people don't tell you about entrepreneurship

2624.56.text: is that sometimes it really, really sucks.

2626.33.text: And so you have to really,

2628.40.text: really love it, because the days that really suck,

2631.13.text: really, really suck and so if you are not passionate about it,

2635.19.text: that's the day where you are kind of like I'm over it,

2637.32.text: this is done, and that's that.

2639.09.text: So that piece is so important.

2641.76.text: And I think people I have seen recently - it's like well,

2644.72.text: I can make money doing this thing but at the end of the day,

2648.14.text: I don't care how much money is in a deal,

2650.25.text: there is going to come a time where something is just going

2653.02.text: to be like not for you and you've got to have that passion

2656.92.text: to say I really believe in this thing or I just love it.

2660.40.text: Everyday I love the job that I have and I love what I get to do.

2664.90.text: And then, I always say knowledge is power.

2668.09.text: So the minute you have an idea - we all have the ability

2671.61.text: to be researchers and you really need to independently -

2674.57.text: not all of your friends and family,

2675.83.text: they love you, they will tell you.

2677.14.text: I was fortunate that my friends and family didn't

2679.40.text: really understand what I was doing so they couldn't

2681.02.text: have told me they thought it was great anyway,

2683.91.text: But what I didn't realize at the time was early on those 40 companies

2687.58.text: that thought that my insights very interesting kind of proved that

2690.06.text: I had a client base before I even knew what that meant.

2692.92.text: And so you really have to spend the time saying what's

2696.83.text: my total market and what's my target market,

2699.21.text: and you always have to be able to answer that question.

2701.92.text: Not I really think this is great, because... It doesn't matter.

2707.07.text: And there are people - I think what's interesting today

2710.76.text: is I really do believe that there are entrepreneurs who

2712.58.text: are creating solutions that will change the world and

2715.52.text: are changing lives everyday and making our lives,

2718.10.text: whether it's more beautiful or easier or more creative,

2721.43.text: but at some point they had to quality that.

2723.88.text: And so I'd say - and quantify it.

2725.93.text: What are your total and target markets and my favorite

2728.95.text: thing is when people say there is no competition.

2732.54.text: As a marketer, I will tell you, consumers can choose to do nothing.

2736.73.text: And so, take a minute and be independent

2740.25.text: and say how do you qualify the idea?

2745.38.text: We all can find a hundred people to say is this something you are

2748.58.text: interested in and then is there a way to prove that concept?

2752.88.text: Can you start to sell something at least to one client and how do you

2757.40.text: get through that sale process and then always be kind of refining,

2761.44.text: don't be so set on this is the way it has to

2764.07.text: go and always be in that research phase.

2766.53.text: But I always hear, especially with technology,

2769.33.text: I think it's a little bit of a different story,

2770.75.text: right, because there is the like analysis paralysis.

2773.95.text: When do you launch your product, when do you let people test it.

2776.51.text: But what's great about technology is consumers

2779.33.text: always from the minute it's launched get to tell

2781.68.text: you what they like and what they don't like.

2783.27.text: And so, get yourself immersed in the ability to hear what your customers

2788.67.text: want from day one I think would be the most important.

2790.75.text: Yes, that is always the most important - the empathy.

2797.59.text: You talked earlier about some problems that marketing has in terms

2801.86.text: of putting pressure on people always to look good, always to...

2808.21.text: Have you found yourself in a position that you

2813.65.text: had to request from a customer that conflicted

2815.53.text: with your ethical views and in case you had it,

2818.29.text: how did you cope with that?

2823.54.text: So the question is have I ever had a client that kind

2825.56.text: of conflicted with our ethical views of the company?

2827.66.text: And so, what most people don't know is that we have

2831.27.text: a panel of our own buzzSpotters that help us determine

2835.53.text: if a client is someone we should work with.

2837.35.text: And that's always a part of our process because I now have 30,000

2845.75.text: people that give their time and energy,

2848.16.text: and when appropriate contract with our clients and are paid to give

2851.36.text: their insights and so that's a really important network and I want

2855.65.text: them to know we're always representing their thoughts and views.

2857.92.text: And so, it's happened a few times where

2860.32.text: things just didn't make sense for us,

2862.17.text: but it comes down for me is someone trying to dictate something

2868.38.text: or are they truly - do they truly believe in their product

2871.14.text: and do they truly believe that they want the customer to

2874.00.text: be as excited about this product as they are.

2876.53.text: So if I have a client that's really not into what they're doing,

2879.76.text: that's not the client for me,

2880.67.text: because the amount of time my team and myself personally,

2884.94.text: that I will dedicate to a project to get something to launch;

2888.23.text: I always say, I can always make more money,

2890.36.text: I can never make more time.

2891.72.text: I can't get that time back.

2893.02.text: And so that for me is the biggest thing;

2895.03.text: do I want to spend my time engaged in this issue with

2897.78.text: this client and obviously 18 years into the business,

2900.58.text: I think I've the ability to say yes and no much

2904.80.text: easier than maybe I even did when I was younger.

2908.62.text: I probably said no to things that I should

2910.22.text: have never said no to but I didn't care.

2912.04.text: So that has always been what has driven me and this agency.

2917.25.text: we might be a lot bigger if I were willing to do things and take on

2920.89.text: some of the clients but if I don't really believe in their product,

2923.98.text: it's not something I'm interested in.

2925.69.text: And I just want to clarify,

2927.24.text: it doesn't mean that I think every product has to be healthy or good.

2931.03.text: I think that there are some brands today that are on this healthy

2934.41.text: good kick that we all know we do not go into those restaurants

2937.56.text: or into those places to get something healthy or good.

2940.07.text: We go in just because we like it and it's interesting.

2943.24.text: So I don't necessarily think that we have to - we are also

2946.89.text: in a place where we're like saying this is bad and that

2949.50.text: is bad and I think as consumers we have to say,

2952.43.text: I like this, so I'm going to do it or I'm interested in this,

2955.11.text: so I'm going to eat this.

2956.60.text: It doesn't mean I'm going eat fast-food everyday.

2959.09.text: But if I want to go have a burger,

2960.61.text: I'm going to have a burger and that's fine.

2961.95.text: And I think that's what I appreciate about

2964.15.text: Millennials is the idea of like it's fine.

2966.72.text: If I want to eat at Chipotle three days a week,

2969.27.text: that's actually cool and it's fine.

2970.64.text: And so I kind of like that approach to things.

2974.43.text: Can I ask you a question about gender and

2978.45.text: I mean, is it ... Interesting question. ...

2981.08.text: So is being female an issue with whatever you want to pursue,

2984.47.text: is being black an issue with whatever you want to pursue?

2986.46.text: And is it an issue, is it a liability, is it an asset?

2990.92.text: What's your read and take both objectively and personally?

2995.56.text: I was asked that question when I got older and I didn't get it.

3000.10.text: And I said, at least speaking from my personal career,

3003.84.text: I came up at a time in '96 before Backstreet Boys and Britney

3008.24.text: Spears and Elle Girl and Teen Vogue and Teen People and

3011.29.text: I kind of rode into the teen wave and I happened to be a

3014.22.text: person who just had more insights than anyone else.

3016.92.text: And so I'm a big believer that,

3019.05.text: at least for me, the only color people saw

3020.99.text: was green and my ability to make money.

3023.89.text: like the only color people saw with me is green.

3028.27.text: I think that this is one of our trends again for next year,

3032.32.text: we're talking about this Power Girl trend

3034.53.text: and I'm a little put off personally,

3037.67.text: it's probably the most controversial thing I'm going to say today,

3040.50.text: by people who think they need to tell girls

3043.78.text: that they can run as fast as boys today.

3045.71.text: I have a niece who is five, I never want her to hear that.

3049.50.text: I want to know - I want her to know to run fast.

3052.41.text: She's growing up - my sister is a sociology professor,

3056.40.text: she thinks her grandma is awesome, her aunt runs a company,

3060.05.text: Phoebe already knows she can do whatever

3061.59.text: she wants to do with her life.

3062.68.text: And so I'm a little put off by that older - and again even my journey,

3067.88.text: right, that would like me saying guys entrepreneurship is so hard.

3071.62.text: You don't know what it's like the last 18 years.

3073.71.text: Like my world, my journey is very different.

3076.56.text: I couldn't build a website for less than $1,000,

3079.58.text: get business cards for less than $35 and have a business

3082.45.text: up and running via LegalZoom in two days.

3085.72.text: That's an opportunity you have and I think I have to respect that.

3090.51.text: And so I'm a little put off by campaigns where

3093.45.text: it's like girls are just as good as boys.

3095.53.text: It's like I don't need a campaign to say that.

3098.43.text: And it's hard because I think that -- are there inequalities that exist?

3104.03.text: But also I can't truly speak to that because I've always created

3106.88.text: my own job and my own opportunity and so I will say one of the

3110.99.text: things that made me really love Dell was they talked about empowering

3115.77.text: women and every time I was in a meeting there,

3117.97.text: there were woman running the show in a way

3121.22.text: and really empowered within that company,

3122.96.text: and so it was great to feel like I wasn't just saying something

3125.49.text: and then sitting in a room with all men dictating and so that's

3128.90.text: important to see that if you're promoting a company culture that

3131.87.text: you're living it and I very much felt that they were.

3134.52.text: But yes, I have a problem with - I think girl power is the

3139.59.text: issue of the day and so people have decided that...

3142.62.text: And there are a lot of trends we can

3144.61.text: speak to in politics that we can see,

3146.67.text: we're trending toward this movement and so I think

3150.56.text: that Millennials see through all of that.

3154.99.text: I just think that pandering - it's like oh,

3157.40.text: now we're going to talk about girls and how awesome girls are.

3160.79.text: I think that toys for girls and things like that - I didn't have

3166.34.text: a course in school that was like this is math for girls.

3170.55.text: I took advanced math and science classes from

3174.33.text: middle school until I graduated at college.

3176.86.text: So ... And it didn't even go through your mind that that was an issue?

3181.31.text: Or that girls were - my girlfriends were

3182.79.text: like sitting next to me in classes.

3183.96.text: This is what we did and so I have a problem when

3186.04.text: we kind of call that out as like hey you,

3189.94.text: Like that's kind of like okay.

3193.18.text: We have time for one final question.

3197.95.text: Any - yes, we got one right there, back there.

3200.42.text: Based on what you just said,

3201.36.text: do you think that being like a good sociologist is kind of an essential

3204.88.text: part of market research and like how have you gained those skills?

3212.01.text: Sorry, do I think that being a good sociologist

3214.07.text: is an important part of my job?

3217.31.text: I, in general, I tend not to hire marketing

3221.76.text: people to work for my company.

3223.41.text: I tend to hire people who come from some sort of social science,

3227.87.text: because I think what's really important is in marketing sometimes

3231.05.text: we're taught to create the voice of the consumer and I feel

3234.43.text: like we're living in a time now where we have to actually

3237.63.text: interpret what the consumer is saying to us and create for

3241.04.text: consumers what they're looking for from us.

3243.25.text: And so I also think it's a very European style of marketing,

3246.81.text: where they really spend a lot of time

3250.34.text: okay, we now have these consumer segments and now we're going to

3253.52.text: create these products to satisfy that and I've seen that through -

3257.64.text: I've had some people work for my agency from Europe and that was

3260.77.text: very much the way they came into the experience versus I have the

3263.93.text: best new car idea and now how are we going to sell it?

3268.11.text: And so I think that I look for people that bring those kind of skills

3273.08.text: to the table because we really are in a time where technology is

3276.83.text: really creating - I keep talking about this democracy where consumers

3281.79.text: can tell us instantly and it's ever happened before.

3285.24.text: I use this example, when I was a teenager if I wanted

3287.60.text: to know if Jane Cosmetics tested on animals,

3289.66.text: I'd call an 800 number on the back of the package,

3293.61.text: I'd ask a question and then go with what they told me.

3296.10.text: Right now if you want to know that,

3297.32.text: you can find out in a minute or less.

3299.03.text: And if you don't like what you see,

3300.36.text: you can start a petition on change.org.

3302.01.text: And so what consumers can do and how quickly and instantly you

3306.34.text: can do it I think has totally changed what we as marketers do.

3311.10.text: And so I really look for people who - cultural anthropologists;

3316.37.text: really interested in what people want and not

3319.22.text: interested in coming in with absolute outcome.
